name: US Laboratory Observation Profile
publisher: Health Level Seven International (Orders and Observations - US Lab)
description: US Realm laboratory result using Quantity Data Type for numeric results

element.name: USLabObsQuantity
element.short: US Realm laboratory result using Quantity Data Type for numeric results
element.definition: US Realm laboratory result using Quantity Data Type for numeric results.  Laboratory results to ordering providers in the ambulatory care setting and "reportable" laboratory test results to local public health agencies.
element.requirements: Observations are a key aspect of healthcare.  This resource is used to capture those that do not require more sophisticated mechanisms.

constraint.human: Component code Shall not be same as observation code
Shall only be present if Observation.value[x] is not present

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the url for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
The base language in which the resource is written.

binding.description: A human language

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.

These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
An Extension

element.name: USLabSpecimenRejectReason
element.definition: Specimen Rejection Reason.
element.requirements: CLIA require a reason when the test is not performed due to an unsatisfactory specimen.

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. element.short: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.definition: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
Value of extension - may be a resource or one of a constrained set of the data types (see Extensibility in the spec for list).

element.name: USLabObservationKind
element.definition: Kind of observation.

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
The laboratory test that was performed.  This is element is bound to LOINC.
element.requirements: The use of the Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes (LOINC) code system is required where a LOINC code is available for the Observation.code, i.e. the being resulted.

binding.description: LOINC codes

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.

element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.definition: This is the laboratory defined display text for the lab test if different from the code display text(s).
element.requirements: Used when the laboratory define how the dsplay text if different from the code display text.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.definition: Describes the general type of observation being made and is used to group or limit searching of observations.

binding.description: Codes for diagnostic service sections

element.definition: This is the actual quantitative (numeric) result.
element.requirements: An observation exists to have a value, though it may not if it is in error, or it represents a group of observations.

binding.description: Codes identifying atomic results of observations when value is type codeableConcept

element.definition: Provides a reason why the expected value in the element Observation.value[x] is missing.
element.requirements: For many results it is necessary to handle exceptional values in measurements.

binding.description: Codes specifying why the result (Observation.value[x]) is missing

element.definition: The assessment made based on the result of the observation.
element.requirements: For some results, particularly numeric results, an interpretation is necessary to fully understand the significance of a result.

binding.description: Codes identifying interpretations of observations

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.

element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.definition: May include statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable values, or information about the source of the value where this may be relevant to the interpretation of the result.
element.requirements: Need to be able to provide free text additional information.

mapping.map: NTE.3 (partner NTE to OBX, or sometimes another (child?) OBX)

element.definition: For lab tests this is the specimen collection date.  For Ask at Order Entry Questions (AOE)'s this is the date the question was asked.
element.requirements: Minimum Precision to Day.

constraint.human: Datetime must be at least to day.

mapping.map: OBX-14-date/time of the observation, and/or OBX-19 after v2.4  (depends on who observation made)

element.definition: The date and time this observation was made available.
element.requirements: Minimum Precision to Day.

constraint.human: Datetime must be at least to day.

mapping.map: OBR.22 (or MSH.7), or perhaps OBX-19 (depends on who observation made)

element.definition: The status of the result value.
element.requirements: Need to track the status of individual results - some results are finalised before the whole report is finalised.

binding.description: Codes providing the status of an observation

mapping.map:
status

Amended & Final are differentiated by whether it is the subject of a ControlAct event with a type of "revise"

element.short: ok | ongoing | early | questionable | calibrating | error +
element.definition: An estimate of the degree to which quality issues have impacted on the value reported.
element.requirements: Not all results are completely reliable, and some are still reported anyway.

binding.description: Codes that provide an estimate of the degree to which quality issues have impacted on the value of an observation

element.definition: Indicates the site on the subject's body where the observation was made ( i.e. the target site).
element.requirements: Knowing where the observation is made is important for tracking if multiple sites are possible.

binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality

element.definition: Indicates the mechanism used to perform the observation.
element.requirements: In some cases, method can impact results and is thus for determining whether results can be compared or determining significance of results.

binding.description: Methods for simple observations

element.short: Unique Id for this particular observation
element.definition: A unique identifier for the simple observation.
element.requirements: Allows observations to be distinguished and referenced.

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
The purpose of this identifier.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.

binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known

element.definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.
element.requirements: Allows users to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

binding.description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose

element.definition: Establishes the namespace in which set of possible id values is unique.
element.requirements: There are many sequences of identifiers.  To perform matching, we need to know what sequence we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular sequence or set of unique identifiers.
element.exampleUri: http://www.acme.com/identifiers/patient or urn:ietf:rfc:3986 if the id itself is a full uri

element.definition: The portion of the identifier typically displayed to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

element.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

element.short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
element.definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.

mapping.map: II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field.  Also Role.scoper

element.short: Who and/or what this is about
element.definition:
The patient, or group of patients, location, or device whose characteristics (direct or indirect) are described by the observation and into whose record the observation is placed.  Comments: Indirect characteristics may be those of a specimen, fetus, donor, 
other observer (for example a relative or EMT), or any observation made about the subject.
element.requirements: Observations have no value if you don't know who or what they're about.

element.definition: The specimen that was used when this observation was made.

element.short: Who is responsible for the observation
element.definition: Who was responsible for asserting the observed value as "true".
element.requirements: May give a degree of confidence in the observation and also indicates where follow-up questions should be directed.

mapping.map:
OBX.15 / (Practitioner)  OBX-16-responsible observer,  PRT-5-participation person:PRT-4-participation='RO' / 
(Device)  OBX-18-equipment instance identifier , PRT-10-participation device:PRT-4-participation='EQUIP' / (Organization)  OBX-23-performing organization name,  PRT-8-participation organization:PRT-4-participation='PO'

element.name: USLabPerformingLabSlice
element.short: Who is responsible for the observation
element.definition: Who was responsible for asserting the observed value as "true".
element.requirements: If lab gernerated results need organization.

mapping.map:
OBX.15 / (Practitioner)  OBX-16-responsible observer,  PRT-5-participation person:PRT-4-participation='RO' / 
(Device)  OBX-18-equipment instance identifier , PRT-10-participation device:PRT-4-participation='EQUIP' / (Organization)  OBX-23-performing organization name,  PRT-8-participation organization:PRT-4-participation='PO'

element.definition: The device used to generate the observation data.

element.short: Healthcare event during which this observation is made
element.definition: The healthcare event  ( e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction ) during which this observation is made.
element.requirements: For some observations it may be important to know the link between an observation and a particular encounter.

element.definition: Guidance on how to interpret the value by comparison to a normal or recommended range.
element.requirements: Knowing what values are considered "normal" can help evaluate the significance of a particular result. Need to be able to provide multiple reference ranges for different contexts.

constraint.human: Must have at least a low or a high or text

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

The value of the low bound of the reference range. If this element is omitted, the low bound of the reference range is assumed to be meaningless. (e.g. reference range is <2.3)  If the low.comparator element is missing, it is assumed to be '>'.

constraint.human: Low range comparators can only be '>' or '>=' or empty

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
The value of the measured amount. The value includes an implicit precision in the presentation of the value.
element.requirements: Precision is handled implicitly in almost all cases of measurement.

mapping.map: PQ.value, CO.value, MO.value, IVL.high or IVL.low depending on the value

element.definition: How the value should be understood and represented - whether the actual value is greater or less than the stated value due to measurement issues. E.g. if the comparator is "<" , then the real value is < stated value.
element.requirements: Need a framework for handling measures where the value is <5ug/L or >400mg/L due to the limitations of measuring methodology.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

binding.description: How the Quantity should be understood and represented

element.definition: A human-readable form of the units.
element.requirements: There are many representations for units and in many contexts, particular representations are fixed and required. I.e. mcg for micrograms.

element.short: System that defines coded unit form
element.definition: The identification of the system that provides the coded form of the unit.
element.requirements: Need to know the system that defines the coded form of the unit.

element.definition: A computer processable form of the units in some unit representation system.
element.requirements: Need a computable form of the units that is fixed across all forms. UCUM provides this for quantities, but SNOMED CT provides many units of interest.

binding.description: UCUM Codes for units of measure

element.definition: The value of the high bound of the reference range. If this element is omitted, the high bound of the reference range is assumed to be meaningless. (e.g. reference range is > 5)  If the low.comparator element is missing , it is assumed to be '<'.

constraint.human: High range comparators can only be '<' or '<=' or empty

element.short: Indicates the meaning/use of this range of this range
element.definition: Code for the meaning of the reference range.
element.requirements: Need to be able to say what kind of reference range this is - normal, recommended, therapeutic, or perhaps what state this reference range applies to (i.e. age, hormonal cycles, etc.).

binding.description: Code for the meaning of a reference range

element.definition: The age at which this reference range is applicable. This is a neonatal age (e.g. number of weeks at term) if the meaning says so.
element.requirements: Some analytes vary greatly over age.

element.short: Text based reference range in an observation
element.definition: Text based reference range in an observation which may be used when a quantitative range is not appropriate for an observation.  An example would be a reference value of "Negative" or a list or table of 'normals'.
A  reference to another resource ( usally another Observation but could  also be a QuestionnaireAnswer) whose relationship is defined by the relationship type code.
element.requirements: Normally, an observation will have either a value or a set of related observations. A few observations (e.g. apgar store) may have both a value and a set of related observations or sometimes questionnaireanswers  from which the measure is derived.

element.short: has-member | derived-from | sequel-to | replaces | qualified-by | interfered-by
element.definition: A code specifying the kind of relationship that exists with the target resource.
element.requirements: A relationship type SHOULD be provided.

binding.description: Codes specifying how two observations are related

element.short: Resource that is related to this one
element.definition: A reference to the observation or questionnaireanswer that is related to this observation.

Some observations have multiple component observations.  These component observations are expressed as separate code value pairs that share the same attributes.  Examples include systolic and diastolic component observations for blood pressure measurement and multiple component observations for for genetics observations.
element.requirements: Component observations share the same attributes in the Observation resource as the primary observation and are always treated a part of a single observation ( they are not seperable).   However, the reference range for the primary observation value is not inherited by the component values and is required when appropriate for each component observation.

Describes what was observed. Sometimes this is called the observation "code".
element.requirements: Knowing what kind of observation is being made is essential to understanding the observation.

binding.description: Codes identifying types of simple observations

element.definition: The information determined as a result of making the observation, if the information has a simple value.
element.requirements: An observation exists to have a value, though it may not if it is in error, or it represents a group of observations.

binding.description: Codes identifying atomic results of observations when value is type codeableConcept

element.short: Why the component result is missing
element.definition: Provides a reason why the expected value in the element Observation.value[x] is missing.
element.requirements: For many results it is necessary to handle exceptional values in measurements.

binding.description: Codes specifying why the result (Observation.value[x]) is missing

element.short: Provides guide for interpretation ofcomponent result
element.definition: Guidance on how to interpret the value by comparison to a normal or recommended range.
element.requirements: Knowing what values are considered "normal" can help evaluate the significance of a particular result. Need to be able to provide multiple reference ranges for different contexts.

element.name: USLabObsQuantity
element.short: US Realm laboratory result using Quantity Data Type for numeric results
element.definition: US Realm laboratory result using Quantity Data Type for numeric results.  Laboratory results to ordering providers in the ambulatory care setting and "reportable" laboratory test results to local public health agencies.

element.name: USLabSpecimenRejectReason
element.definition: Specimen Rejection Reason.
element.requirements: CLIA require a reason when the test is not performed due to an unsatisfactory specimen.

element.name: USLabObservationKind
element.definition: Kind of observation.
The laboratory test that was performed.  This is element is bound to LOINC.
element.requirements: The use of the Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes (LOINC) code system is required where a LOINC code is available for the Observation.code, i.e. the being resulted.

binding.description: LOINC codes

element.definition: This is the laboratory defined display text for the lab test if different from the code display text(s).
element.requirements: Used when the laboratory define how the dsplay text if different from the code display text.

element.definition: This is the actual quantitative (numeric) result.
Actual numeric result.
The Unified Code for Units of Measure (the UCUM) is a system of codes for unambiguously representing measurement units to both humans and machines.
element.requirements: The units are coded in UCUM.

element.definition: UCUM code.

binding.description: UCUM Codes for units of measure
Codes identifying interpretations of observations

element.definition: For lab tests this is the specimen collection date.  For Ask at Order Entry Questions (AOE)'s this is the date the question was asked.
element.requirements: Minimum Precision to Day.

constraint.human: Datetime must be at least to day.

element.requirements: Minimum Precision to Day.

constraint.human: Datetime must be at least to day.

element.requirements: If lab gernerated results need organization.
